title: ASX to open lower as Brexit rally is shortlived
text:
Wall Street rose as upbeat earnings from Netflix and Morgan Stanley affirmed a strong start to the US reporting season while the dollar fell against the euro as the common currency got a lift on the long-awaited Brexit deal.

Big players like Coca-Cola, American Express and Schlumberger report their results Friday.

US housing starts fell by 9.4 per cent to 1.26 million (annualised) units in September, after surging by 15.1 per cent in August. Market expectations were set on a milder decline of -3.2 per cent.

Production at US factories fell in September by the most in five months, depressed by an autoworkers' strike at General Motors, sluggish global demand and the trade war. Production at manufacturers declined 0.5 per cent last month, weaker than the median forecast in a Bloomberg survey of economists, Federal Reserve data showed.

Today's agenda

Local: None

Overseas data: China industrial production September; China retail sales September and GDP Q3; Japan national CPI September; US leading index September; US Philadelphia Fed Index.

Market highlights

Advertisement

ASX futures down 27 points or -0.4% to 6637 near 3.45 am AEDT

AUD +1% to 6826 US cents

On Wall St: Dow flat S &P 500 +0.2% Nasdaq +0.3% at 12.26pm in New York

In New York: BHP -1% Rio +0.5% Atlassian -1.1%

In Europe: Stoxx 50 -0.3% FTSE +0.2% CAC -0.4% DAX -0.1%

Spot gold +0.4% to $US1496.53 an ounce at 12.42pm New York time

Brent crude -0.9% to $US58.86 a barrel

US oil -0.7% to $US53.01 a barrel

Iron ore -0.9% to $US87.06 a tonne

Dalian iron ore +0.1% to 612 yuan

LME aluminium -0.1% to $US1727 a tonne

LME copper +0.2% to $US5739 a tonne

2-year yield: US 1.59% Australia 0.75%

5-year yield: US 1.57% Australia 0.78%

10-year yield: US 1.76% Australia 1.10% Germany -0.40%

10-year US/Australia yield gap: 66 basis points

From today's Financial Review

Huge challenges loom for Johnson after striking Brexit deal: After years of torturous negotiations, Britain and the European Union have finally agreed to a Brexit deal - but Boris Johnson has failed to get the DUP onside and still faces the challenge of pushing the deal through Parliament.

The BCA's new boss is bald, ballsy and from tech: The next president of the Business Council of Australia has a shaved head, doesn't wear ties and will be the first boss of the chief executives' lobby group aged under 50.

Generators call for notice as smelters teeter on the brink: Coal-fired generators have called for "sufficient notice'' before an aluminium smelter is allowed to exit the National Electricity Market.

United States

US stocks moved broadly higher in midday trading after several large companies delivered surprisingly good results. A rebound in Netflix subscribers in the third quarter drove shares in the firm 9 per cent higher even as analysts warned conservative estimates for the next three months may be a hint of less certain times ahead.

Advertisement

Bank stocks made strong gains as bond yields rose. Morgan Stanley climbed 3.1 per cent after reporting solid third-quarter profit and revenue.

Europe

British stocks had a short lived rally after news of the Brexit deal broke - heading up before investors realised Boris Johnson did not have the majority to push the deal through Parliament.

The UK's FTSE mid-cap stocks index was well off its day's high and was last trading up 0.3 per cent. The blue-chip exporter-heavy FTSE 100 index rose 0.8 per cent on sterling's reversal.

London's benchmark FTSE index jumped 0.61 per cent but the broad-market pan-European STOXX 600 lost most of its gains, rising 0.17 per cent. The FTSEurofirst index of leading regional shares rose 0.17 per cent.

JPMorgan's basket of London-listed companies that make their cash at home has enjoyed a meteoric rally in the past week.

In this period it has vastly outperformed the FTSE 100 and FTSE 250. The benchmark is considered a barometer of Brexit worries.

Asia

Advertisement

Hong Kong stocks climbed to end at a one-month high on Thursday, on hopes that more stimulative measures would be rolled out to bolster the island city's growth amid months-long protests.

The Hang Seng index rose 0.7 per cent while the China Enterprises Index gained 0.5 per cent.

Nine major banks in Hong Kong have agreed to adopt a number of measures to support small and medium enterprises in Hong Kong, the central bank said on Wednesday, as four months of anti-government protests start taking its toll on local businesses.

The city's hedge fund industry has seen its biggest quarterly outflow in 10 years, with $1.4 billion being pulled from local funds.

Elsewhere, sentiment was tepid. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index lost 0.1 per centwhile the Shanghai Composite index slipped 0.2 per cent.

Currencies

The Brexit deal sent the pound up as much as 1.1 per cent to a five-month high and within a whisker of $US1.30, but the gains were temporary. The pound was down 0.2 per cent by midday Thursday (early Friday AEDT) hitting $US1.2793 - far below the $US1.2988 level touched earlier in the day.

Sterling has been on a rollercoaster ride recently, and is up 7 per cent since early September when it hit the lowest since October 2016 at $US1.19.

Advertisement

The euro was buoyed by news of a deal and was last up 0.4 per cent at $US1.1116 while the dollar index fell 0.3 per cent.

US Treasury yields rose to their highest in almost a month on news of the Brexit deal. “The market is at this point really heavily influenced, if not totally driven, by headlines related to Brexit and whether or not it looks like a deal is on,” said Thomas Simons, a money market economist at Jefferies in New York.

Benchmark 10-year notes rose as high as 1.799 per cent, a level last reached on September 19, before dropping back to 1.754 per cent.

A euro zone bond sell-off cooled. "The market is very wary at this point in time as it is still very unclear if the deal will go through on Saturday," said Nordea Asset Management strategist Sebastien Galy.

Germany's 10-year government bond yield, which rose as much as 7 basis points to -0.33 per cent on optimism around the deal earlier on Thursday, was down 1 bp on the day at -0.40 per cent.

Commodities

Oil prices fell as industry data showed a larger-than-expected increase in US inventories but losses were limited by a Brexit rally.

US crude inventories soared by 10.5 million barrels to 432.5 million barrels in the week to October 11, the American Petroleum Institute's weekly report showed, ahead of official government stocks data.

Advertisement

Analysts had estimated US crude inventories rose by 2.8 million barrels last week.

Copper inched higher. "All eyes are on the trade war at the moment and little else matters," said BMO Capital Markets analyst Kash Kamal.

"The moves we are seeing in metals aren't very big... the market is thinking let's get this mini-deal from last week ratified before any real excitement."

LME nickel inventories slid to their lowest in more than seven years, with headline stocks falling 2760 tonnes to 88,302 tonnes, the lowest since December 2011.

Australian sharemarket

The Australian sharemarket has broken its five-session streak of growth as one of the nation's most prominent technology stocks faced fraud accusations amid weak production updates from the resources sector.

These problems led to the benchmark S &P/ASX 200 Index dipping 51.8 points, or 0.8 per cent, to 6684.7 points on Thursday. The broader All Ordinaries Index was also down across the trading session, shedding 51.7 points – or 0.8 per cent – to 6791.5 points.

Street Talk

Logistics company maps out Silk-y path to ASX

Bankers chase dwindling invites to block party

Chinese bidders read up on PE-owned Modern Star
description: Australian shares are set to open lower despite positive movement on Wall Street and a final breakthrough deal on Brexit.
